article_title: Humana suddenly drops Baylor doctors out of network
article_text:
Humana suddenly drops Baylor doctors out of network

Photo: Courtesy Of Jodie Teuton Jodie Teuton says her 14-year-old daughter, Victoria, lost...

Jodie Teuton and her daughter drove six hours from southern Lousiana to Houston's Baylor College of Medicine, wondering if this time it would be different. For five years and more doctor visits than she could count she had searched for the reason behind her child's worsening problem with balance and motor skills.

article_metadata.description: National health policy experts, too, call the decision both unusual and troubling because it extends the ways insurance companies are finding to narrow coverage options even as the federal health care law works to expand access for more Americans.  Orlowski said there have been scattered examples across the country of some marketplace plans severely limiting access to faculty doctors connected with academic hospitals.  In the weeks after her daughter's appointment with Jankovic she switched insurance for the 300 employees at her family's truck dealership to Humana because she thought Victoria's care would be in network.  Dr. Stephen Sigworth, vice president and chief medical officer at Baylor College of Medicine, worries the decision will most hurt the patients who, like Teuton's daughter, have complicated diagnoses and benefit from the expertise of faculty doctors.  For those commercial plan individuals affected by this change, we communicated quickly and clearly about the change in network status with Baylor MedCare.  Teuton's letter from Humana said if a member had a "serious" condition they could fax the patient's name and ID number and information about the condition if they wanted to stay in network.  Consumers locked into group plans may be more likely to give up and either find other care within the insurer's network or pay the higher out-of-pocket costs, she said, adding that she has since decided to fight the decision.  Narrowing of provider networks by insurance companies is not new, but the practice has really taken hold with the implementation of the Affordable Care Act as consumers and politicians demand lower costs.  Many people seeking individual plans under the ACA are willing to swap a restricted choice of providers for lower prices.  "Narrow networks fit very well in the exchanges," said Paul Ginsburg, director of public policy at the Schaeffer Center for Health Policy and Economics at the University of Southern California.  There is a quickly shifting landscape so teaching hospitals and consumers need to be very careful about what is in-network, cautioned Gerald Kominski, director of the University of California-Los Angeles Center for Health Policy Research.  Kominski thinks it is the role of state and federal regulators to provide strong oversight to make sure insurance companies are transparent with decisions and to protect consumers.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jenny Deam
